title: Synchronization failed
body:
#### System information

Geth version: `1.8.18-unstable-66debd91`
OS & Version: OSX `Darwin C02X6344JG5K 18.0.0 Darwin Kernel Version 18.0.0: Wed Aug 22 20:13:40 PDT 2018; root:xnu-4903.201.2~1/RELEASE_X86_64 x86_64`
Commit hash : ([66debd91d9268067000c061093a674ce34f18d48](https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/commit/66debd91d9268067000c061093a674ce34f18d48))

```
MacBook Pro (15-inch, 2018)
2.9 GHz Intel Core i9
32 GB 2400 MHz DDR4
External SSD APFS formatted 
G|Drive mobile SSD R-Series 1TB 560 MB/s Mo/s
```

#### Expected behavior

Full synchronization


#### Actual behaviour

Stalled synchronization


#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour
`geth --cache=16000 --rpc console --rpcapi db,eth,net,web3,personal --rpcaddr 127.0.0.1 --datadir /Volumes/external/Ethereum/ --maxpeers 256 --syncmode fast --ethash.dagdir /Volumes/external/Ethereum/`


#### Backtrace
```

```

```
> web3.net.peerCount
34
```


```
> eth.syncing
{
  currentBlock: 6059859,
  highestBlock: 6555792,
  knownStates: 66342024,
  pulledStates: 66340406,
  startingBlock: 0
}
```
````
$ sudo sntp -sS time.apple.com
sntp 4.2.8p10@1.3728-o Tue Mar 21 14:36:42 UTC 2017 (136.200.1~2533)
2018-10-21 04:07:59.382574 (+0700) -0.004316 +/- 0.003945 time.apple.com 17.253.4.125 s1 no-leap
````

````
$ go version
go version go1.11.1 darwin/amd64
````
Impressive hardware specs. This non-sync issue seems common. I'm wondering if a newer optimization in 1.8.x broke something. Wonder if. 1.6 or 1.7 work fine.

Thanks for the compliment regarding the hardware specifications @jyap808. I'm trying it now with [Geth/v1.7.3-stable-4bb3c89d/darwin-amd64/go1.9.2](https://gethstore.blob.core.windows.net/builds/geth-darwin-amd64-1.7.3-4bb3c89d.tar.gz).
Unfortunately, that didn't seem to make a difference at all. @jyap808
Ah good to know. Thanks for reporting back. Cheers
I reformatted the external drive and tried again from the start and got a clean sync. So I'm not sure.
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.
